docs.lead_paragraph: Last summer, as a 72-year-old friend exited from a strip mall in Connecticut, her car was struck broadside by an van she had not seen coming. She died three days later of complications related to her injuries. Just one year earlier, a 70-year-old woman I know was in a similar accident. She pulled out of a filling station on Long Island into the path of a semi. Her husband eventually died from his injuries; she survived, but after many hospitalizations and with permanent disabilities.

headline.main: Some Caution Signals for Older Drivers

docs.abstract: First of two Jane E Brody Personal Health column on added risks to road safety posed by older drivers; notes that by year 2020, one in five drivers will be 65 or older; describes vision deficits, body changes, congnitive changes and common health problems that can impairing driving of older people; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW I CAME INTO MY INHERITANCE And Other True Stories By Dorothy Gallagher 187 pages. Random House. $22.95. BALD IN THE LAND OF BIG HAIR A True Story By Joni Rodgers 253 pages. HarperCollins. $24. Cancer and communism may not be laughing matters, but they're funnier than you'd think in two new memoirs by unusually candid and gutsy women. Joni Rodgers, who was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and writes frankly about her experiences in ''Bald in the Land of Big Hair,'' tries to find a joke at every possible turn, as in: ''Why didn't the home health nurse cross the road? Because the chicken's H.M.O. wouldn't approve it!''

headline.main: Facing Chemo or Pinkos, and Still Smilin'

docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews Bald in the Land of Big Hair: A True Story by Joni Rodgers; reviews How I Came Into My Inheritance: And Other True Stories by Dorothy Gallagher; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: COUNTLESS pharmacies serve the nearly 20 million people living in this enormous city, including a chain called Drogeria São Paulo that features 24-hour franchises nestled next to all-night gas stations. Inside one of those drug stores on Vincenzo Rao Street, a large red and white sign hanging from the ceiling declares: ''We have generics. Look at our list.'' An arrow points down to a six-page list printed from a Web site and propped on a counter display. Generic drugs are crucial to the many poor and working class people in this urban sprawl, and the list is meant to help them find what they need. It provides the generic names of drugs, their corresponding brand name and identity of the original manufacturer, the name of the Brazilian pharmaceutical producing the generic, and whether it is generally dispensed at a hospital or pharmacy.

headline.main: Patents; In health emergencies, Brazil allows the copying of drugs, to the dismay of American companies.

docs.abstract: Sabra Chartrand Patents column on Brazilian patent laws, how they differ from American laws and US drug manufacturers' dismay over 1999 presidential decree that allows government to license drug patents in cases of national emergency (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RUNNING his fingers over a stock chart, Arthur C. Spinner was telling a common story, but from an uncommon point of view. The stock of a British company called Bookham Technologies, he said, went public in April at $15.83 and, riding a wave of enthusiasm for fiber optics stocks, floated to a high of $84.63 by July. To British investors, Bookham resembled a local version of hot American stocks like JDS Uniphase and Sycamore Networks. It had a new way to manage ever-expanding fiber optic networks more efficiently, and it even earned early backing from Alberto W. Vilar, a prominent technology investor and philanthropist.

headline.main: Hedge Funds That Excel (And Avoid The Exotic)

docs.abstract: Survey of hedge funds that have profited handsomely for their wealthy and institutional investors at a time when markets have fallen; says the industry's current leaders focus on technology, telecommunications or health care; focuses on Spinner Asset Management, Pequot Capital Management and Orbimed Advisors; graph; photos (M)

byline.original: By DANNY HAKIM with GERALDINE FABRIKANT

docs.lead_paragraph: Burgers grilling, fruit punch staining baby faces, summer scenting the air. In a courtyard on 129th Street, the tenants are having a barbecue. The architecture is Mediterranean in feel, a plaza flanked by two buildings freshly painted peach and yellow. To the front, a gate to protect the pristine setting. To the rear, a Technicolor splash of green: a garden with gazebo.
docs.abstract: First article in series An American Block: Life on 129th Street; focuses on revival of once ravished neighborhood; black, white and Hispanic young professionals now live on street that in 1994 was almost uniformly black and bent by poverty and violence; years have brought unprecedented economic growth, startling drop in crime and drugs, immigrant influx, city drive to redevelop housing and rise of neighborhood organizations that stress restoration; residents comment; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a striking shift, leaders of the nation's most widely used program to discourage drug use among schoolchildren have acknowledged that their strategy has not had sufficient impact and say they are developing a new approach to spreading their message. DARE -- for Drug Abuse Resistance Education -- has grown so rapidly since its founding 18 years ago that it is now taught in 75 percent of school districts nationwide and in 54 other countries.

headline.main: ANTIDRUG PROGRAM SAYS IT WILL ADOPT A NEW STRATEGY

docs.abstract: Leaders of DARE, nation's most widely used program to discourage drug use among schoolchildren, acknowledge their strategy has not had sufficient impact and say they are developing new approach to spreading their message; DARE--Drug Abuse Resistance Education--is now taught in 75 percent of school districts nationwide and in 54 other countries; its efforts have drawn increasing criticism that they do not work; DARE officials have long dismissed criticism, but now even surgeon general and National Academy of Sciences have issued reports saying DARE's approach is ineffective; as result, DARE is introducing new program, aimed at older students than current one and relying more on having them question their assumptions about drug use than on listening to lectures on subject; controlled studies of 50,000 students will begin in six cities and their suburbs, including New York, in fall (M)
